journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of Conservative Dentistry and Endodontics

title-group.article-title: Local drug delivery for regeneration and disinfection in endodontics: A narrative review

article-meta.aff: Department of Conservative Dentistry and Endodontics, Faculty of Dental Sciences, Ramaiah University of Applied Sciences, Bengaluru, Karnataka, India

author-notes.corresp: Address for correspondence: Dr. Anu Elsa Swaroop, Department of Conservative Dentistry and Endodontics, Faculty of Dental Sciences, Ramaiah University of Applied Sciences, Bengaluru, Karnataka, India. E-mail: anuelsa.310@gmail.com

abstract.p: Local Drug Delivery Systems (LDDSs) represent a significant development in endodontic therapy, offering targeted, effective treatment options for managing root canal infections and regenerative outcomes. LDDS can be customized to deliver antimicrobial agents and/or bioactive components to the specific site to address challenges associated with resistant microbial species and enhance regenerative outcomes. Further research in this area is essential to optimize these systems to improve clinical success. This article attempts to review the existing literature on the different LDDS in endodontics. Relevant scientific literature related to the topic was searched in PubMed, Google Scholar, and Scopus, critically analyzed and their data were extracted.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The oral cavity hosts a diverse biome of microorganisms that is crucial for maintaining oral health. Any disruption in this balance can result in dental caries, gingivitis, and periodontitis, potentially resulting in infection and tooth loss. Endodontic infections may require systemic management along with mechanical and chemical debridement of the root canal system. These antibacterials can cause unfavorable systemic adverse effects such as hypersensitivity, gastrointestinal problems, and drug resistance. Patient compliance is also important for its efficacy.

To overcome the above challenges, various Local Drug Delivery Systems (LDDSs) have been developed which can target medications to specific sites, enhancing therapeutic effect, with reduced systemic toxicity has found favor, particularly in the treatment of cancer, ocular diseases, and Alzheimer’s.[1] Controlled delivery of antibacterial agents incorporated into fibers for treatment of periodontal pockets was found to reduce the microbial flora and improve the clinical manifestation of the disease in a study done by Goodson et al.[2] Since then, LDDSs have found applications in other branches of dentistry such as oral and maxillofacial surgery,[3] implant dentistry,[4] endodontics,[5] and cariology.[6]

Polymicrobial nature of endodontic infection coupled with the persistent biofilm and the hostile root canal ramifications makes disinfection a challenge for the clinician.[5] Researchers are focusing on eliminating these challenges using LDDS in the form of nanoparticles,[678910111213141516] nanofibers,[171819202122] hydrogels,[23242526] liposomes,[27] etc., incorporated into root canal sealers,[1528] obturating materials and cements[2930] to allow deeper penetration of antimicrobial agents, analgesics, and even growth factors for effective disinfection and pulp regeneration.

LDDS seems to offer a promising therapeutic strategy in endodontics; however, selection of the right delivery system is the key to success. Current reviews on LDDS in endodontics are limited. This article aims to compile various LDDS and assess their endodontic applications.

sec.title: LITERATURE REVIEW
sec.p: Drug delivery systems (DDSs) improve therapeutic effectiveness and safety by controlling pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics.
Key advantages of LDDSs include:

list-item.label: (i)
list-item.p: Targeted delivery of therapeutic agents to the desired site

list-item.label: (ii)
list-item.p: Controlled and sustained release of drugs, antibiotics, or growth factors

sec.p: For an antimicrobial agent to be recommended for periodontal or intracanal use, it should be able to reach the intended site of action while maintaining an adequate concentration and effectiveness for sufficient duration and exhibit substantivity.[31]

sec.title: Local drug delivery system in restorative dentistry and endodontics
sec.p: DDSs have been extensively studied for controlled, sustained release of antibacterial and remineralizing agents for dental caries prevention and treatment. Nanoscale DDSs, such as liposomes, micelles, and polymer nanoparticles, have gained attention for their ability to locally deliver antibacterial agents such as peptides, triclosan, and chlorhexidine (CHX) which can help prevent secondary caries and stimulate pulp regeneration.[27]

A bio-adhesive chitosan/fluoride microparticle system was developed which demonstrated a sustained fluoride release over 6 h and good mucosal adhesion.[32] In addition, dual-functional DDSs with both antibacterial and remineralizing properties have been explored. Triclosan-loaded G4-COOH poly amido amine (PAMAM) demonstrated extended release of the antibacterial drug and dentin remineralization, offering a novel approach for both dental caries treatment and dentin repair.[33]

Antibacterial nanoparticles (e.g., Ag and ZnO) and remineralizing agents such as nano-amorphous calcium phosphate can be incorporated into adhesives and composite resins.[3233] Nanofibers are being explored in mucoadhesive DDSs for the prevention and control of caries.[34] A study by Boaro et al. reported the use of CHX/montmorillonite particles capable of releasing the drug for up to 10 days.[35] Metal particles, particularly silver, are also used for their broad-spectrum antibacterial properties enhancing the effectiveness of dental resin.[36]

LDDS offers targeted therapeutic solutions with applications in pulp capping, pulpotomy, intracanal medication, canal irrigation, root canal sealers, and filling material such as gutta-percha and regenerative endodontics.

sec.title: Local drug delivery system in vital pulp therapy and regenerative endodontics
sec.p: Vital pulp therapy (VPT) is a minimally invasive approach aimed at preserving vital pulp tissues, maintaining tooth function, and conserving tooth structure. It involves creating a conducive environment for pulpal healing and regeneration. Current biomaterials for pulp capping including calcium hydroxide (CH), mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA), and its modifications, and the next-generation Bioceramic/Bioactive glass-based cements act by chemical stimulation of pulp. Future advances would involve the use of growth factors, bone morphogenic proteins, and fibroblast growth factors to induce the natural dentinogenesis. Specific biomaterials in the form of micro/nanosized particles and injectable hydrogels combined with stem/progenitor cells are being explored for regenerating the dentin-pulp complex and stimulating hard tissue formation.[23]

Polymer-based LDDSs can effectively control the release of therapeutic agents, including both hydrophobic and hydrophilic drugs. CH-loaded poly (lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA) nanoparticles or in the form of hydrogels demonstrated a prolonged profile of drug release and excellent penetration into the dentinal tubules compared to CH alone.[7] Bioactivity, biocompatibility, and biodegradability of natural polymer-based hydrogels such as collagen, gelatin, and fibrin, make them highly effective in biomedical applications, especially tissue engineering and drug delivery. In contrast, synthetic polymer-based hydrogels such as polylactic acid based, polyethylene glycol (PEG) based, and self-assembling peptides, offer better mechanical strength, durability, and thermal stability. Combining these polymers into hybrid hydrogels such as alginate/laponite and PEG-based natural polymers provides an optimal environment for pulpal healing and endodontic regeneration.[37]

Nanofibers hold promise for pulp tissue engineering and regenerative endodontics, as they can biomimetically recreate the pulp-dentin complex and mimic native pulp functions.[17] In addition, polycaprolactone electrospun nanofibrous scaffolds have been shown to support pulp tissue regeneration.[18]

Main carriers for bioactive dentin proteins identified for VPT include solutions in reagents, microspheres, and scaffolds.[38] Since the preservation of a dentinal construct is essential for VPT, bioceramic-based LDDSs could be a valuable candidate for use in VPT modalities.[39]

Tissue engineering approaches focus on the inclusion of cell-friendly bioactive scaffolds that encapsulate and release antimicrobial substances, regenerative cells, and growth factors. Scaffolds include natural biomaterials such as collagen, alginate, and chitosan or host-derived scaffolds such as blood clot and autologous platelet concentrate. Synthetic scaffolds include hydraulic calcium silicate cements and synthetic polymers. These scaffolds deliver and maintain antimicrobial efficacy at reduced dosages while promoting stem cell viability and proliferation.[40] Biocompatible scaffolds such as electrospun polydioxanone (PDS), ciprofloxacin-containing scaffolds, and others have demonstrated effectiveness against various pathogens and biofilm models.[41424344]

Li et al. reported successful pulp regeneration in a mature tooth with a closed apex using a hierarchical nanofibrous microsphere scaffold (heparin-conjugated gelatin nanospheres). This system effectively binds vascular endothelial growth factor (VGEF) to heparin and prevents growth factor degradation while allowing its sustained release to regenerate pulp-like tissues in the apical and middle thirds of the root.[45]

Alginate/laponite hydrogel microspheres have the capability to deliver dental pulp stem cells and VEGF for regenerative endodontics. Use of delivery systems based on microspheres, hydrogels, and fibers are being used for sustained release in endodontics, with hybrid hydrogels showing significant promise for enhancing regenerative outcomes.[46]

Bioceramics such as silica, calcium phosphates, and calcium silicates are recognized for their bone-healing properties, while hydroxyapatite and tricalcium phosphate microparticles provide biocompatibility and aid form hard-tissue barriers.[4748] Biomaterial scaffolds (natural, host-derived, and synthetic) with precise fabrication onto the targeted structures mimick the tissue’s complexity advancing regeneration from the lab to clinical practice.[495051]

While evidence on LDDSs in VPT is limited, further research is needed through experimental, in vitro, and in vivo studies, including animal models and randomized controlled trials. A comprehensive evaluation should include monitoring patient signs, performing clinical exams, and assessing radiographic findings, dentinal bridge formation, and pulpal tissue healing.[48] The summary of LDDS in VPT and regenerative endodontics is described in Table 1.

caption.p: Summary of local drug delivery system in vital pulp therapy and regenerative endodontics

fn.p: VPT: Vital pulp therapy, CH: Calcium hydroxide, LDDS: Local drug delivery system, DAP: Double antibiotic pastes, PCL: Polycaprolactone, PLGA: Poly (lactic-co-glycolic acid), CSnp: Chitosan nanoparticles, Dex-CSnp: Dexamethasone conjugate chitosan nanoparticles, HDAC: Histone deacetylase, miRNA: Micro RNA, VEGF: Vascular endothelial growth factor, DPSC: Dental pulp stem cell, ALP: Alkaline Phosphatase

sec.title: Local drug delivery system in endodontic disinfection
sec.p: Eliminating intracanal microorganisms and their by-products from the intricate root canal anatomy, including isthmuses and accessory canals remains a significant challenge in endodontics. LDDSs offer a promising approach for targeted disinfection and enhancing healing.

Recent research has focused on the use of micro- and nanoparticles in endodontic disinfection. For example, bioceramic microparticles coated with PLGA have proven effective in delivering antibiotics to the root canal and enhancing disinfection.[53] PLGA microparticles are recognized for their sustained drug-release capabilities.[54] PLGA microparticles loaded with amoxicillin and PLGA/calcium phosphate cement containing growth factors have been developed for root canal disinfection and regeneration.[55]

Alvarez et al. proposed the use of microencapsulation techniques and microparticles to deliver various agents, including antibiotics and growth factors, to the root canal in both in vitro and in vivo studies.[56] Adding amoxicillin-loaded microspheres to MTA and using antibiotic-loaded microcarriers with calcium silicate-based cement have yielded promising outcomes.[57]

Hydrogels have also shown promise in regulating the porosity and viscosity of endodontic intracanal scaffolds. Recently, Ribeiro et al. introduced an injectable matrix metalloproteinase-responsive chlorhexidine (CHX) halloysite aluminosilicate nanotube (HNT) within a gelatin methacryloyl hydrogel. This formulation aims for sustained intracanal application against endodontic infections, leveraging its affinity for cell tissue and degradability.[25] However, further research is needed to explore the full potential of hydrogels in endodontic treatment.

Studies by Alghofaily et al. and Sousa et al. have explored the potential of polymer-based nanofibers for intracanal disinfection.[1920] Clindamycin-modified triple antibiotic PDS-based nanofibers have shown efficacy against various root canal microorganisms.[21] These can be used to transport triple antibiotic paste (TAP) and modified TAP to target microorganisms and bacterial biofilms. Biologically synthesized silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) have been developed as modern antimicrobial agents with promising advantages. The effectiveness of fungal-sourced AgNPs against Porphyromonas gingivalis, Bacillus pumilus, and Enterococcus faecalis biofilms show promise in combating endo-perio pathogens.[58]

Huang et al. developed CHX-loaded devices made from ethyl cellulose, creating a needle-like structure suitable for easy insertion into the root canal. These microparticle formulations have been shown to access unreachable areas of the root canal.[59] Sousa et al. developed amoxicillin-loaded microparticles (5–38 μm) through spray-drying, preserving the drug’s antimicrobial activity, with the minimum inhibitory concentration against E. faecalis maintained for 6 days.[54] Incorporating gold nanoparticles into Advanced-platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) has the potential to continuously release growth factors and keep the canal sterile, preventing E. faecalis and promoting successful revitalization and regeneration. The concurrent utilization holds the potential for improving revascularization in necrotic immature permanent teeth.[10]

Pagonis et al. utilized PLGA nanoparticles (150–200 nm) loaded with methylene blue to address E. faecalis infections.[11] PLGA submicron particles loaded with CHX, calcium, and phosphorus referred to as P-CaPC, demonstrated strong antibacterial activity, biocompatibility, and the ability to infiltrate dentinal tubules, potentially enhancing dentin microhardness.[60] Collagen sponges containing amoxicillin and CHX displayed sustained antimicrobial effects in vitro and effectively disrupted mature biofilms ex vivo.[61]

TAP combined with chitosan nanoparticles and activated with PDT resulted in a significant decrease in microbial colony count.[62] Tubular 3D drug delivery constructs made from PDS and three antibiotics (metronidazole, ciprofloxacin, and minocycline) were developed to function at lower concentrations than clinical TAP during disinfection. These constructs fit the anatomy of immature teeth, replicating biofilm conditions in dentinal tubules. They effectively eliminated intracanal biofilm, demonstrating similar efficacy to TAP.[44] A study by Pandey et al. demonstrated that chitosan nanoparticles have higher antimicrobial effectiveness compared to CH and normal saline when dealing with E. faecalis biofilm.[12] Bioglass nanofibers, coated with dexamethasone, and PRF as scaffolds for immature necrotic teeth, facilitated apexogenesis.[22]

Lee et al. developed nano-diamond embedded gutta-percha (NDGP) functionalized with amoxicillin, a broad-spectrum antibiotic to target existing microbes and prevent reinfection in the root canal system. Incorporation of nanodiamonds improved the mechanical strength and handling properties of gutta-percha during clinical use. Further, a randomized, single-blind interventional study compared NDGP to unmodified gutta-percha, with follow-up appointments at 3 and 6 months. No adverse events were reported, and the healing of lesions was confirmed in patients treated with NDGP. This study lays the groundwork for further clinical applications of nanodiamonds and similar nanomaterials.[2930] The summary of LDDS in endodontic disinfection is described in Table 2.

caption.p: Summary of local drug delivery system in endodontic disinfection

fn.p: DDS: Drug delivery system, LDDS: Local DDS, AgNPs: Silver nanoparticles, GO: Graphene oxide, DMAHDM: Dimethylamino hexadecyl methacrylate, NAg: Nanoparticles of silver, NACP: Nanoparticles of amorphous calcium phosphate, MWCNTs: Multi-walled carbon nanotubes, CHX: Chlorhexidine, TAP: Triple antibiotic paste, mTAP: Modified TAP, MMP: Matrix metalloproteinase, GelMA: Gelatin methacryloyl, HNT: Halloysite Nanotubes / Halloysite aluminosilicate nanotubes, 3D: Three-dimensional, ATAB: Alkyl trimethyl ammonium bromide, NDGP: Nanodiamond embedded gutta-percha, E. faecalis: Enterococcus faecalis, MIC: Minimum inhibitory concentration, DPSCs: Dental pulp stem cells, Ag-GO: Silver Graphene Oxide, PRF: Platelet Rich Fibrin

sec.title: CHALLENGES AND RESEARCH GAPS IDENTIFIED IN LOCAL DRUG DELIVERY SYSTEM
sec.p: Significant challenges and research gaps remain despite promising advances in the field of LDDS. Patients may experience allergic or hypersensitivity reactions to any of the constituents in the LDDS. Majority of research related to LDDS is in the preliminary stage performed under a controlled in vitro environment which cannot be extrapolated to a clinical scenario. Most studies do not assess the quality and bioavailability of the agent at the site which influence the therapeutic efficacy and performance. Developing these systems requires collaboration among industry, academia, and regulatory agencies. In endodontics, there is an insufficient number of clinical studies to come to a quantitative analysis regarding LDDS. Most of the studies focus on the effect of the LDDS on the microflora and stem cell survival. Interaction of these systems with irrigants and adhesives and its influence on the physical properties of the tooth needs to be assessed. Further clinical studies evaluating practical applicability and long-term effect of the LDDS on pulpal health and regenerative outcomes need to be assessed.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: LDDSs are designed to release drugs in a controlled/sustained manner at the local site with minimum side effects. Various forms of LDDS have been explored which show promising results and may play a productive role in VPT and tissue regeneration. Further, in vivo studies are essential to substantiate the effect of these in the context of healing and regeneration.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: There are no conflicts of interest.
